p.s: Since brass, not stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea / But sad mortality o'er-sways their power(l. 1-2).
The first lines of the first quatrain describe that no element of nature can survive the sad mortality (l. 1).
The enumeration emphasizes that indeed nothing in nature has the ability to do so; not even the boundless sea (l. 1) which is often used as a symbol of freedom and peace.
The truth of death, the sad mortality (l. 2) is going to destroy their power (ref. l. 2), Shakespeare is stating that neither nature nor humans can overcome time.
It is so powerful and invincible that mortal things cannot keep up with it and will eventually suffer defeat from its hands.
How this rage shall beauty hold a plea, / Whose action is no stronger than a flower?(l. 3-4).
The writer is probably refferingreferring to the heyday of nature and humans: the most precious and beautiful time of onesone's life is their youth.
But it will eventually experience an end because time causes beauty fade, people to age and life end.
Therefore the beauty of youth and life is not able to withstan the rage (l. 3) of time.
The writer is also drawing a comparison between life and a flower (ref. l. 4).
Life and humans are as fragile and delicate as a flower, unable to fight the unbeatable power of time.
Just like a flower we will fade when our time has come.
The second quatrain also puts emphasis on the transitoriness of youth and life.
O, how shall summer's honey breath hold out / Against the wrackful siege of batt'ring days(l. 5-6).
The peak, the crown of onesone's life, the youth is described through the metaphor summer's honey breath.
This comares youth to a sweet summer breeze which is often realized as one of the most pleasant experiences, but unlike time, is something limited that eventually fades away.
Summer ends and winter awaits.
This beautiful experience is taken away from us and we cannot do anything about it.
When rocks impregnable are not so stout, / Nor gates of steel so strong, but time decays?(l. 7-8).
Time is impregnable (l. 7), strong and impossible to defeat.
No strength and pwer of this world can withstand time which will bring our death as the end of its natural cause (ref. l. 8).
The rhetorical question (ref. l. 7-8) stresses this exact phenomenon: Nothing can slow down or beat time, it will eventually overcome us.

body.p: The last quatrain personifies time.Shall time's best jewel from time's chest lie hid? / Or what strong hand can hold his swift foot back?(l. 10-11). This stresses, once again, that time gifts us with its best jewel (l. 10) being the youth but only for limited time.We cannot hold his swift foot back (l. 11).The writer is hyperaware of the fact which he puts emphasis on it by incorporating several rhetorical questions in a row (ref. l. 10-12).

p.s: The last two lines of the last quatrain also form an Anaphoraanaphora (ref. l. 11-12), laying great stress on time's transitory gift to human kind.
Time spoils us with the gift of our precious youth.
It is so precious and sweet that we want to taste and keep it forever, which is impossible.
Time brutally takes it away from us and there is no escape, no antidote to it.
O, none, unless this miracle have might, / That in black in my love may still shine bright(l. 13-14).
As usual the couoplet resolves the established theme in the previous quatrains.
Shakespeare makes use of the word miracle as a symbol with which he underlines the impossibility of defeating and withstanding love.
A miracle does not follow the laws of nature and therefore remains some thing of rare possibility.
Assuming that no miracle it will take place, Shakespeare expresses that art is able to overcome time.
While youth, life and nature will one day come to an end, words and poems will be passed on until eternity.
The writer engraves his feelings and his verses so that they can treasure his most precious thoughts.
Art is the only thing that proves to withstand time, refusing to age.
The sonnet can be read in a melodic way through Shakespeare's use of language f.e. for example anaphoras, alliterations and word plays.
Examples can be found in the following lines: nor stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea (l. 1), steel so strong (l. 8), shall summer's honey breath hold out (l. 5).
In this sonnet Shakespeare describes the everlasting power of time in comparison to the fragility and limits of the humankind and nature.
Our youth is as precious and sweet as a summer breathe: we never want to let go but there's no chance nonot to.

Considering Shakespeare's other sonnets it is clear that one of his main themes was the passage of time and mortality of the human kind.
Sonnet 65 is also one those sonnets in which he emphasizes the inferiority of mortality in comparison to time.
This dilemma is often portrayed as a dead end by Shakespeare.
Humans want to enjoy the privilege of youth and life until forever.
This longiglonging clashes with the concept of time which is why Shakespeare declares humans as defeated.
Art is the only way to let us love on forever.
Words, verses and poems are able to achieve what we will never be able to: withstand time.
